animalOfTheDay.name: spider
facts: The venom of most spiders is harmless to humans, with only a few species being dangerous.
Some spiders can 'balloon' by releasing silk threads to catch the wind and travel long distances.
All spiders produce silk, but not all spiders spin webs to catch prey.
Spiders are not insects; they are arachnids, with eight legs and two body segments.

calendar.name: serval
facts: Servals have the longest legs relative to body size of any cat.
They can leap 10 feet straight up to catch birds in flight.
Servals have excellent hearing and can detect rodents underground.
They are solitary hunters and mark their territory with urine and scent glands.

calendar.name: siberian husky
facts: Siberian huskies are a medium-sized working dog breed.
They are known for their striking blue or multi-colored eyes and thick double coat.
Siberian huskies were originally bred as sled dogs.
They are energetic and require a lot of exercise.

calendar.name: skunk
facts: Skunks are known for their ability to spray a foul-smelling liquid as a defense mechanism, which can reach up to 10 feet.
They are immune to snake venom and will sometimes eat venomous snakes.
Skunks are nocturnal and have poor eyesight but an excellent sense of smell and hearing.
Before spraying, skunks usually give a warning by stomping their feet or raising their tail.

calendar.name: snail
facts: They have thousands of tiny teeth on their tongue-like radula, which they use to scrape food.
The largest land snail, the African giant snail, can grow up to 15 inches long.
Snails are hermaphrodites, meaning each individual has both male and female reproductive organs.
Snails can sleep for up to three years if the weather isn't favorable.

calendar.name: snow leopard
facts: Snow leopards are known as 'ghosts of the mountains' due to their elusive nature.
They are unable to roar but communicate with chuffing sounds and growls.
They have thick fur and wide, fur-covered feet that act as natural snowshoes.
Snow leopards can leap up to 50 feet in a single bound.

calendar.name: snowy owl
facts: Their feathers are nearly entirely white, providing perfect camouflage in snowy environments.
Unlike most owls, they are diurnal and hunt both day and night in the Arctic tundra.
Snowy owls can detect prey moving beneath the snow using their exceptional hearing.
Snowy owls are one of the largest owl species, with a wingspan of up to 5 feet.

calendar.name: spider
facts: Spiders are not insects; they are arachnids, with eight legs and two body segments.
All spiders produce silk, but not all spiders spin webs to catch prey.
Some spiders can 'balloon' by releasing silk threads to catch the wind and travel long distances.
The venom of most spiders is harmless to humans, with only a few species being dangerous.

randomAnimals.name: wasp
facts: Wasps produce paper by chewing wood fibers mixed with saliva.
Mud daubers build tubular nests with paralyzed spiders as living food for larvae.
Fig wasps co-evolved with figs – each fig species has its own wasp pollinator.
Parasitoid wasps lay eggs in hosts; larvae eat prey alive while avoiding vital organs.

randomAnimals.name: parrotfish
facts: Parrotfish can change their gender during their lifetime.
They produce sand by grinding up coral with their teeth—up to 200 pounds per year.
At night, some species secrete a mucus cocoon around themselves for protection.
Parrotfish get their name from their beak-like teeth used to scrape algae from coral.

randomAnimals.name: heron
facts: They can swallow fish whole, thanks to their flexible necks and sharp beaks.
Some heron species use bait, like twigs or insects, to lure fish closer.
Herons have a unique hunting technique, standing perfectly still before striking at prey.
Herons often nest in colonies called 'heronries,' high in trees or on cliffs.
